Expectation1: Ensure compliance with safety and regulatory standards
Situation1: A recently updated standard will apply to the upcoming release, and evidence of conformity is required
Expectation2: Follow the instructions and guidelines provided by the volunteer coordinator
Situation2: An urgent directive from the coordinator outlines mandatory procedures that must be followed to avoid shutting down the service.
Story:
I sat at my desk, the hum of the office blending with the buzz of my phone. As an engineer, I was responsible for ensuring our new product met every updated safety standard. The latest regulation had just come into effect, and my manager expected me to provide clear evidence of compliance before the release next week. The pressure was on; any oversight could mean a costly recall or worse.

At the same time, my phone vibrated with a message from the volunteer coordinator at the community center. The service we provided was at risk—an urgent directive had come through, outlining new mandatory procedures. The coordinator’s message was clear: if we didn’t implement these changes immediately, the center would have to shut down, leaving dozens of people without support.

I stared at my screens, feeling the weight of both worlds. My team at work relied on me to uphold our standards, while the community counted on me to follow the coordinator’s instructions to keep the service running. Both roles demanded my full attention, both with consequences I couldn’t ignore. My mind raced, torn between the expectations pressing in from every side.
